title: Green Infracstructure, enviromental perception and spatial behaviour.
abstractText:
The aims of this CASE collaborative PhD studentship were to examine the complex nature of green infrastructure development, its meanings, its perceptions (by users) and use as an approach to landscape planning.  

Three key themes were examined:

  1. conceptual development and definitions of green infrastructure
  2. the role of perceptions in the valuation and use of green infrastructure resources, particularly ecological, psychological and social constructions and how these affect personal and communal landscape interpretations
  3. the use of green infrastructure by practitioners, particularly how the principles of green infrastructure have been translated into landscape management. 

The study used a multi-method approach based on qualitative data collection including interviews with academics and practitioners, analysis of green infrastructure policy and implementation documents, and a visual preference survey with students and conservation volunteers using photographs of a location or landscape that highlighted a number of characteristics associated with green infrastructure.   

The analysis indicated that a green infrastructure approach to planning can be useful to meet the complex challenges of landscape planning. In particular green infrastructure can provide the basis for considering and developing more integrated planning policy, strategic thinking, multi-functionality, ecological and landscape connectivity, access to green space and more sustainable urban development.
impactText: This funding was for a collaborative CASE studentship. The studentship is now complete and the candidate passed his PhD examination successfully. The thesis work has been the basis for his present research as an academic and he has published various papers as a follow up to his doctoral studies.
findingsText: This grant was a collaborative CASE PhD studentship carried out in partnership with the North East Community Forests. The candidate completed the thesis successfully and passed his PhD. He is now working in academia. The PhD provided the basis for the candidates present research and his further career, firstly in practice and now in academia. Environment
